main.name: Chad Luke Fischer
main.occupation: Software Developer, Researcher, and UX Designer
main.description: I am currently a junior at the University of Southern California, where I am pursuing a B.S. in Computational Linguistics and a minor in User Experience. I have always had an aptitude for creativity, and I take pride in projects that utilize this skill. My combined strengths of writing, art, and programming give me a unique perspective when working to solve difficult problems.
main.bio: I am proficient in a wide degree of languages including: [C++, Java, Javascript, Python, Pytorch, React, Matlab]. In the future, I hope to work with artificial intelligence, specifically natural language processing and speech recognition/synthesis. Currently, I am looking for a technological internship for summer 2020.
main.contactmessage: Please reach out for questions or inquiries:

education.description: Pursuing a Bachelor of Science in Computational Linguistics with a minor in User Experience
AP Courses: Computer Science A, Studio Art, Calculus AB, European History, American History, English Language and Composition, English Literature

work.title: Undergraduate Associate Researcher (Natural Language Processing)
work.description: Part of a research effort aimed to build AI that generates narrative summary based on events that occur in US Army training simulations. Utilized computer vision and NLP to build textual summary given a sequence of events.

work.title: Data Specialist
work.description: Data entry and analytics for optical character recognition (OCR) software that extracts relevant data fields from photographic receipts. Analyzed and recorded key-words across multiple languages (Japanese, German, French, Italian) in order to optimize data accuracy.

projects.title: Thera-aid
projects.category: Prototype for theraputic wellness IOS application

projects.title: USC ICT Narrative
projects.category: Link to the Narrative Department at USC Institute for Creative Technology

testimonials.text: In deep learning, thereâ€™s no data like more data. The more examples of a given phenomenon a network is exposed to, the more accurately it can pick out patterns and identify things in the real world
Machine intelligence is the last invention that humanity will ever need to make
